title: Font with tail on the 'z'
content:
Hi,

I’m looking for a serif font similar to Clarendon (see ning.com) with a tail on the lower case ’z’. I love the ’g’ in that font but my name doesn’t have a g in it.

Can anyone suggest a suitable font? Its for a masthead / logo on a website.

thanks!

 [‹ Tuscon AZ Type meet-up?](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122063226/http:/www.typophile.com/node/48365 "Go to previous forum topic") [Buy Cadena for cheap and awesome. ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122063226/http:/www.typophile.com/node/43560 "Go to next forum topic")
author: codecowboy

comments.content:
Hi

I do not have a certain typeface-suggestion at hand, but you could ask around if someone is willing to create a custom logotype if you are willing to make a job offer out of it.

I for one would definitely be interested in developing those letters for you.

Also, a custom logo would be much more unique then setting the wordmark in a commercial typeface.

Best regards

Steffen

The lower case italic in Weiss has a little tail.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122063226im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/z_5766.gif)

thanks. I know illustrator so can probably do it myself. The tail would be much more like the ’g’ from Clarendon rather than the one from Weiss. Is there a technical term for this ’tail’ so I can do some investigating?
I don’t think you’ll find a typeface with ’z’ that has what I would call a ’g’s “ear”. This should be done by hand, as steffen suggests.

Attached a (very) fast sketch of a letter ’z’ from clarendon roman. Maybe it’s a possibility to start if you decide to do it yourself.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122063226im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/clarend_alt_z_5920.gif)
thanks for the advice (and the sketch!). I’ll come back here with any results.
